title: Scarlett Moffatt thanks fans after British Tribe Next Door airs
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Scarlett Moffatt has thanked viewers for their support after the first episode of her controversial Channel 4 documentary The British Tribe Next Door aired last night.

The new show sees the former Gogglebox star and her family relocate to Namibia with a complete replica of their home to live alongside the Himba tribe for four weeks.

Before it even aired, the show received backlash by the bucketload with many branding the concept ‘raicist’, ‘problematic’ and ‘inappropriate’.

But Scarlett reached out on Twitter to thank her fans for praising the debut installment, posting to her 654,800 followers: ‘Thank you so so so much for your positive comments for my family and for my Himba friends.’

The episode itself saw Scarlett praised by the tribe for her ‘rolls of fat’, with the I’m A Celebrity… Get Me Out Here! star admitting to Ruth Langsford and Eamonn Holmes on This Morning that she’s never felt ‘so not judged’.

Scarlett tweeted after the show (Picture: Twitter)

A replica of Scarlett’s family home was rebuilt in Namibia (Picture: Channel 4)

‘I just feel like a lot of my days are consumed with how I look and you see your reflection and yeah, it’s not a thing there,’ she added.

Scarlett also defended the show building an exact replica of her family home, which was complete with running water, WiFi and a washing machine, on the tribe’s land.

Ruth told her: ‘There could be people who would say could have just gone to live with the Himba people in their mud huts, so what was the premise of taking the house?’

‘Then they wouldn’t have seen how we live,’ Scarlett replied, before adding that the locals wanted the house taken down.

Scarlett also came close to tears over the ‘eye-opening’ cultural differences during the installment, which we branded ‘every bit painful as it is problematic’ in our review.

Viewers also seemed infuriated by the episode, with one slamming: ‘Who in the world thought this was a good idea?’

Advertisement

Echoing a similar sentiment, another added: ‘Ummm who thought #thebritishtribenextdoor was a) a good idea and b) in any way appropriate to air in BLACK HISTORY MONTH ??!!! Nobody considered the coloniser/colonised issues clearly represented here at all did they?’

However, some were left impressed by what they saw and enthused: ‘I think The British Tribe Next Door is going to turn out as one of the most fascinating programmes I have ever seen.

‘It’s not insulting to the Namibians, but a total wake up call for us. By the end of it, I bet we’ll all look differently at our live.’

The British Tribe Next Door continues Tuesday at 9.15pm on Channel 4.
